docs.title: Chapter 1: Introduction to Fluid Mechanics
docs.text:
Definition of Fluid Mechanics

Fluid Mechanics is the branch of physics that studies the behavior of fluids (liquids and gases) at rest (fluid statics) and in motion (fluid dynamics).

docs.title: 1. Continuum Hypothesis
docs.text:
Continuum Hypothesis

The Continuum Hypothesis assumes that fluid properties like density, pressure, and velocity are continuously distributed in space. This allows the use of differential calculus. The fluid is treated as a continuous medium, ignoring molecular structure.

Note: This assumption is valid when the characteristic length scale is much larger than the molecular mean free path.

docs.title: 2. Classification of Fluids and Flow Types
docs.text:
Classification of Fluids

  • Ideal Fluid: No viscosity, incompressible
  • Real Fluid: Viscous, may be compressible
  • Newtonian Fluid: Shear stress is linearly proportional to the rate of strain
  • Non-Newtonian Fluid: Nonlinear stress-strain relationship

Types of Fluid Flow

  • Steady vs Unsteady: Time-independent vs time-dependent
  • Uniform vs Non-uniform: Same properties across a section vs varying spatially
  • Laminar vs Turbulent: Smooth orderly flow vs chaotic flow
  • Compressible vs Incompressible: Varying vs constant density

docs.title: 3. Basic Fluid Properties
docs.text:
Density (\( \rho \))

Density is the mass per unit volume:

\[ \rho = \frac{m}{V} \]

Typical value: For water at 4°C, \(\rho = 1000 \, \text{kg/m³}\)

Viscosity (\( \mu, \nu \))

  • Dynamic viscosity \(\mu\) relates shear stress to velocity gradient:
\[ \tau = \mu \frac{du}{dy} \]
  • Kinematic viscosity \(\nu = \mu / \rho\)

Surface Tension (\( \sigma \))

\[ \sigma = \frac{F}{L} \]

Water at 20°C: \(\sigma \approx 0.072 \, \text{N/m}\)

Compressibility (\( \beta \))

\[ \beta = -\frac{1}{V} \left( \frac{\partial V}{\partial P} \right)_T \]

Pressure (\( P \))

\[ P = \frac{F}{A} \]

docs.title: 4. Introduction to Fluid Statics and Dynamics
docs.text:
Fluid Statics and Dynamics

  • Fluid Statics: Fluids at rest. Focuses on pressure distribution, buoyancy, forces on submerged bodies.
  • Fluid Dynamics: Fluids in motion. Focuses on velocity fields, flow patterns, kinematics, and conservation laws.

Key Distinctions Between Statics and Dynamics

  • Statics: \(\vec{v} = 0\), only pressure and body forces.
  • Dynamics: \(\vec{v} \neq 0\), velocity, acceleration, and shear stress are important.
  • Flow visualization:
    • Streamlines: Lines tangent to velocity vectors
    • Pathlines: Trajectories of individual particles

docs.title: Example 1: Surface Tension Force Around a Ring
docs.text:
Problem: Calculate surface tension force around a circular ring of radius \(r = 2 \, \text{cm}\), if \(\sigma = 0.072 \, \text{N/m}\)

Solution:

\[ L = 2 \pi r = 2 \pi (0.02) = 0.1257 \, \text{m} $$ $$ F = \sigma \cdot L = 0.072 \cdot 0.1257 = 0.00905 \, \text{N} \]

Answer: \(F = 9.05 \, \text{mN}\)

docs.title: Example 2: Shear Stress in a Newtonian Fluid
docs.text:
Problem: A Newtonian fluid has \(\mu = 0.001 \, \text{Pa·s}\), velocity gradient \(du/dy = 100 \, \text{s}^{-1}\)

Solution:

\[ \tau = \mu \frac{du}{dy} = 0.001 \cdot 100 = 0.1 \, \text{Pa} \]

Answer: \(\tau = 0.1 \, \text{Pa}\)

docs.title: 1. Hydrostatic Pressure
docs.text:
Hydrostatic Pressure

Hydrostatic pressure is the pressure exerted by a fluid at equilibrium due to the force of gravity. In a static fluid, pressure increases with depth.

\[P = P_0 + \rho g h\]

Where:

  • \(P\) = absolute pressure at depth \(h\)
  • \(P_0\) = pressure at the surface (reference)
  • \(\rho\) = fluid density
  • \(g\) = acceleration due to gravity (9.81 m/s²)
  • \(h\) = depth from the surface

This assumes the fluid is incompressible and at rest. Hydrostatic pressure is important in analyzing forces on submerged surfaces like gates, dams, and tanks.

Total force on a submerged vertical surface:

\[F = \rho g \bar{h} A\]

Where \(\bar{h}\) is the depth to the centroid and \(A\) is the surface area.

docs.title: Example: Pressure at Depth
docs.text:
Problem 1

A container is filled with oil of density \(\rho = 850 \, \text{kg/m}^3\). What is the pressure at a depth of \(h = 3 \, \text{m}\)? Assume atmospheric pressure is not included.

Solution:

\[P = \rho g h = 850 \times 9.81 \times 3 = 25,027.5 \, \text{Pa}\]

Answer: \(P = 25,027.5 \, \text{Pa}\)

Another example: Find the pressure 5 m below water (\(\rho = 1000 \, \text{kg/m}^3\)) open to atmospheric pressure \(P_0 = 101325 \, \text{Pa}\):

\[P = 101325 + (1000)(9.81)(5) = 150,375 \, \text{Pa}\]

docs.title: 2. Pascal’s Law
docs.text:
Pascal's Law

Pascal's Law states that the pressure applied to a confined incompressible fluid is transmitted undiminished in all directions.

\[\frac{F_1}{A_1} = \frac{F_2}{A_2} = \Delta P\]

Where:

  • \(F_1, F_2\) = forces on two pistons
  • \(A_1, A_2\) = areas of the pistons
  • \(\Delta P\) = pressure transmitted equally

Output force formula:

\[F_2 = F_1 \frac{A_2}{A_1}\]

source

Example:

  • Small piston: \(A_1 = 0.01~\text{m}^2\), \(F_1 = 100~\text{N}\)
  • Large piston: \(A_2 = 0.5~\text{m}^2\)
\[F_2 = 100 \cdot \frac{0.5}{0.01} = 5000~\text{N}\]

docs.title: 3. Manometers and Pressure Measurement
docs.text:
Manometer Principle

source

Measures pressure difference via fluid height difference:

\[\Delta P = \rho g h\]

Where:

  • \(\rho\) = density of fluid
  • \(g\) = acceleration due to gravity
  • \(h\) = height difference

Example:

Mercury (\(\rho = 13600 \ \text{kg/m}^3\)) in U-tube shows \(h = 0.15 \ \text{m}\):

\[\Delta P = 13600 \cdot 9.81 \cdot 0.15 \approx 19,998 \ \text{Pa}\]

docs.title: 4. Hydrostatic Forces on Plane and Curved Surfaces
docs.text:
Hydrostatic Force on a Plane Surface

Total hydrostatic force on a vertical plane:

\[F = \rho g \bar{h} A\]
  • \(F\) = total force
  • \(\bar{h} = h_\text{top} + \frac{h}{2}\) = depth of centroid
  • \(A\) = area of surface

Center of pressure:

\[h_{cp} = \bar{h} + \frac{I_G}{\bar{h} A}\]

Moments of inertia \(I_G\):

  • Rectangle (base \(b\), height \(h\)): \(I_x = \frac{b h^3}{12}\)
  • Circle (radius \(R\)): \(I = \frac{\pi R^4}{4}\)
  • Triangle (base \(b\), height \(h\)): \(I_x = \frac{b h^3}{36}\)

docs.title: Example: Vertical Gate
docs.text:
A rectangular gate: \(b=2~\text{m}\), \(h=4~\text{m}\), submerged with top edge \(h_\text{top} = 1~\text{m}\).

  1. Depth to centroid:

    \[\bar{h} = 1 + 4/2 = 3~\text{m}\]

  2. Hydrostatic force:

    \[F = 1000 \cdot 9.81 \cdot 3 \cdot (2 \cdot 4) = 235,440~\text{N}\]

  3. Moment of inertia:

    \[I_G = \frac{2 \cdot 4^3}{12} = 10.67~\text{m}^4\]

  4. Center of pressure:

    \[h_{cp} = 3 + \frac{10.67}{3 \cdot 8} = 3.44~\text{m}\]

Hydrostatic Forces on Curved Surfaces

For curved submerged surfaces:

  • Horizontal component: \(F_H = \rho g \bar{h} A_v\)
  • Vertical component: \(F_V = \rho g V_f\)
  • Resultant: \(F_R = \sqrt{F_H^2 + F_V^2}\), \(\theta = \tan^{-1}(F_V/F_H)\)

docs.title: 5. Buoyancy and Archimedes' Principle
docs.text:
Buoyancy

Buoyant force is the upward force due to pressure difference:

  • Depends on fluid density and displaced volume
  • For floating bodies, only a portion of volume is displaced
  • Applies to gases as well

docs.title: Example: Flat Plate
docs.text:
Flat plate: thickness \(s=0.05~\text{m}\), area \(A=2~\text{m}^2\), submerged at \(h=1~\text{m}\):

\[P_\text{top} = 1000 \cdot 9.81 \cdot 1 = 9810~\text{Pa}$$ $$P_\text{bottom} = 1000 \cdot 9.81 \cdot 1.05 = 10300.5~\text{Pa}\] \[F_\text{top} = 9810 \cdot 2 = 19620~\text{N}$$ $$F_\text{bottom} = 10300.5 \cdot 2 = 20601~\text{N}\] \[F_b = F_\text{bottom} - F_\text{top} = 981~\text{N}\]

Displaced fluid: \(V = 0.05 \cdot 2 = 0.1~\text{m}^3\) Weight: \(1000 \cdot 9.81 \cdot 0.1 = 981~\text{N}\)

docs.title: Archimedes' Principle
docs.text:
\[F_b = \rho_f g V_d\]
  • \(F_b\) = buoyant force
  • \(V_d\) = volume of fluid displaced

Conditions:

  • Floats: \(F_b \ge W\)
  • Sinks: \(F_b < W\)
  • Neutral: \(F_b = W\)

docs.title: Example: Sinking Metal Cube
docs.text:
Volume: \(0.02~\text{m}^3\), density \(7800~\text{kg/m}^3\)

  • Buoyant force: \(196.2~\text{N}\)
  • Weight: \(1529.2~\text{N}\)
  • Sinks since \(W > F_b\)

docs.title: 6. Stability of Floating and Submerged Bodies
docs.text:
Stability Criteria

Key points:

  • \(G\) = center of gravity
  • \(B\) = center of buoyancy
  • \(M\) = metacenter

Conditions:

  • Stable: \(M\) above \(G\)
  • Unstable: \(M\) below \(G\)
  • Neutral: \(M = G\)

Metacentric height:

\[GM = BM - BG, \quad BM = \frac{I}{V}\]

docs.title: Example: Floating Pontoon
docs.text:
Base: \(5 \times 3~\text{m}\), displaced water \(V = 4~\text{m}^3\), CG = 0.6 m above base

\[ I = \frac{3 \cdot 5^3}{12} = 31.25~\text{m}^4 $$ $$ BM = \frac{31.25}{4} = 7.8125~\text{m} $$ $$ GM = 7.8125 - 0.6 = 7.21~\text{m (Stable)} \]
